subteams.name: Dissolved Organic Matter
subteams.description: DOM (dissolved organic matter) is dedicated to improving the removal process of organic matter from water sources. DOM naturally forms as organic materials, such as feces and decaying leaves, break down. When DOM reacts with coagulants, the contaminants aggregate into larger clusters known as flocs, making them easier to separate during the filtration stage. Currently, at the AguaClara Gracias plant, maple leaves break down in water and create issues with taste and visual appeal.

subteams.name: Ram Pump
subteams.description: Ram Pump focuses on the research, design, and fabrication of the AguaClara Vertical Ram Pump (ACVRP), a proprietary, open-source technology developed within AguaClara. The team designs experiments and fabricates parts to test different pump optimization methods. Its purpose within the AguaClara plant is to pump filtered water from the bottom to chemical stock tanks located at higher elevations without using electricity and minimizing clean water waste. This eliminates the need for operators to move clean water themselves manually.

subteams.name: Upflow Anaerobic Sludge Blanket (UASB)
subteams.description: The UASB subteam is testing a gravity-powered reactor for wastewater treatment at the Ithaca Area Wastewater Treatment Facility (IAWWTF). Transportation to the plant has been provided by students on the team with personal vehicles. The team also has a contract (contact Professor Ruth Richardson for more information) with IAWWTF to conduct COD, BOD, phosphorous, and fecal coliform tests in the IAWWTF lab space, under the close supervision of IAWWTF lab technicians.

subteams.name: Floc Filtration
subteams.description: Floc Filtration is investigating the potential for a floc recycle system in the AguaClara clarifier. In the current system, flocs in the floc filter become full as they capture more primary particles, reducing their ability to capture additional particles and decreasing the clarifier's removal efficiency over time. To maintain efficiency, the subteam proposes a recycle system that would use shear force to break up flocs, maximizing their surface area and allowing them to continue capturing primary particles. This system aims to improve the clarifier's efficiency while using a similar coagulant dosage, enhancing its relevance to AguaClara.

subteams.name: Plantita (PF200)
subteams.description: PF200 (Plantita) is a prefabricated water treatment plant designed for a community of 300. The team's goal is to implement a PF200 pilot model in Puerto Rico that is acclimated to its climate. Puerto Rico has frequent storms that lead to highly turbid water. Often, these rural communities cannot afford to hire a full-time operator to monitor the plant's performance and adjust its coagulant dosing as necessary. Plantita is currently creating an automated coagulant dosing model to respond to fluctuating turbidites with minimal interference from an operator.

subteams.name: Coagulant Dosing
subteams.description: Coagulant Dosing is working on an equation to output the correct dosage for Plantita. The AguaClara Pilot Plant at Cornell’s Water Filtration Plant provides an opportunity test new changes on a 0.5 L/s AguaClara plant and compare it to a conventional water treatment plant. The first technology to test is the ability to control the coagulant dose automatically. As advances are made in floc recycling for enhanced floc filter performance it may be possible to test that technology using the 3' diameter bent pipe clarifier.

subteams.name: Floc App
subteams.description: Floc App is focused on accurately sizing and counting flocculation particles in turbid water by using machine learning, computer vision, and image segmentation. The app's goal is to quantify the floc particles that are not caught by the filter, helping to determine the optimal coagulant dosage. By developing a full-stack application for global use by plant operators, serving over 100,000 people, the team aims to adjust coagulant levels and potentially eliminate the need for expensive turbidimeters, improving efficiency for AguaClara plants.

subteams.name: Plant Operations Smartphone Tracker (POST)
subteams.description: POST is designing a way to streamline how water operators in Honduras monitor, record, and analyze water filtration data. Developed with Flutter, Figma and Postman, this Android application provides a user-friendly, offline-capable survey form for operators to submit various metrics and generate visual data representations. By replacing paper records, the app simplifies data management, enhances communication with AguaClara Reach and the development team, and improves overall efficiency for operators in the field.

subteams.name: Public Relations
subteams.description: The Public Relations team of AguaClara Cornell increases the project’s exposure within Cornell and globally by maintaining a consistent brand that reflects its innovative and sustainable ideals. They boost team pride and campus visibility through merchandise, social media, and recruitment efforts. Public Relations also ensures a uniform message with press kits and templates, representing AguaClara to campus, implementation partners like AguaClara Reach and APP, and managing internal logistics.

subteams.name: Investments
subteams.description: The Investments team works with AguaClara Reach and Cornell’s fundraising and grant departments to secure funding and expand AguaClara technology worldwide. On campus, they lead fundraising campaigns like fall crowdfunding and spring Giving Day and assist research subteams with EPA proposal submissions. Their ultimate goal is to take the lead in grant applications and fundraisers, ensuring funding for summer research, materials, and trips to Honduras.
